column1: Agriculture and Food -- Meat Consumption: Per capita
column2: Provided by the World Resources Institute (http://www.wri.org)

column1: Source: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)
Population Division of the Department of Economic and Social Affairs of the United Nations Secretariat.   World Population Prospects: The 2004 Revision. Dataset on CD-ROM.  New York: United Nations.
Meat consumption per capita refers to the total meat retained for use in country per person per year. Total meat includes meat from animals slaughtered in countries
column5: and meat from all other domestic or wild animals such as camels

column1: Years Covered and Frequency of Update:
Data are available for most countries and regions from 1961 to 2003. Data are updated annually by the Food and Agriculture Organization.  FAO posted the 2003 updates on-line in 2004.
Per capita calculations were conducted by WRI using FAO data on meat production and trade
column2: and using U.N. data on population.   Meat consumption was calculated using a trade balance approach -  total production plus imports

column1: Production data was collected mostly through annual FAO surveys to governments. Data has been grouped in 12 month periods ending 30 September of the years stated in the tables. For example
column2: animals enumerated in a given country at any time between 1 October and 30 September of the following year are shown under the latter year. Data for most species is calculated using the number of animals slaughtered
column3: and the average dressed carcass weight
column4: to estimate the corresponding production of meat. Data relate to animals slaughtered within national boundaries

column2: trade data have been supplied by governments through magnetic tapes
column5: FAO questionnaires. For European community countries
column7: data obtained from EUROSTAT have been used. In addition
column8: maximum use has been made of the magnetic tapes provided by the United Nations Statistical Division. To make the coverage of this yearbook as complete as possible
column9: official trade data have sometimes been supplemented with data from unofficial sources. Use has also been made of trade information supplied by other national or international agencies or organizations.

column1: Further information on these data and the Food and Agriculture Organization can be obtained at: http://apps.fao.org
Data is reported by individual countries
column2: which may have varying capacities for data collection.  However
column3: the reporting of agricultural production and trade data are governed by established accounting procedures and are generally considered to be reliable.  The FAO attempts to ensure the quality of these data
column4: but cannot ensure that all data are accurate.

column1: In the absence of reliable sources or when information for the latest year is not available in time
column2: figures for quantities and values are estimated on the basis of trade returns of trading partners.
